## Data  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 102, 675, 528]]<|/det|>
speed of light in free space, \(c = 3.00\times 10^{8}\mathrm{m s}^{- 1}\) permeability of free space, \(\mu_{0} = 4\pi \times 10^{- 7}\mathrm{Hm}^{- 1}\) permittivity of free space, \(\epsilon_{0} = 8.85\times 10^{- 12}\mathrm{Fm}^{- 1}\) elementary charge, \(e = 1.60\times 10^{- 19}\mathrm{C}\) the Planck constant, \(h = 6.63\times 10^{- 34}\mathrm{Js}\) unified atomic mass constant, \(u = 1.66\times 10^{- 27}\mathrm{kg}\) rest mass of electron, \(m_{\mathrm{e}} = 9.11\times 10^{- 31}\mathrm{kg}\) rest mass of proton, \(m_{\mathrm{p}} = 1.67\times 10^{- 27}\mathrm{kg}\) molar gas constant, \(R = 8.31\mathrm{JK}^{- 1}\mathrm{mol}^{- 1}\) the Avogadro constant, \(N_{\mathrm{A}} = 6.02\times 10^{23}\mathrm{mol}^{- 1}\) the Boltzmann constant, \(k = 1.38\times 10^{- 23}\mathrm{JK}^{- 1}\) gravitational constant, \(G = 6.67\times 10^{- 11}\mathrm{Nm}^{2}\mathrm{kg}^{- 2}\) acceleration of free fall, \(g = 9.81\mathrm{m s}^{- 2}\)

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 108, 558, 145]]<|/det|>
\[s = ut + \frac{1}{2} at^{2}\] \[\nu^{2} = u^{2} + 2as\]

\[W = \rho \Delta V\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[444, 195, 536, 225]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[444, 235, 521, 251]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[444, 262, 570, 295]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[444, 339, 608, 375]]<|/det|>
\[\nu = \nu_{0}\cos \omega t\] \[\nu = \pm \omega \sqrt{(\chi_{0}^{2} - x^{2})}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[444, 386, 536, 418]]<|/det|>
\[V = \frac{Q}{4\pi\epsilon_{0}r}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[428, 426, 624, 445]]<|/det|>
\[1 / C = 1 / C_{1} + 1 / C_{2} + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[444, 459, 592, 477]]<|/det|>
\[C = C_{1} + C_{2} + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 490, 527, 513]]<|/det|>
\[W = \frac{1}{2} QV\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 528, 592, 545]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 561, 624, 579]]<|/det|>
\[1 / R = 1 / R_{1} + 1 / R_{2} + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[444, 594, 560, 610]]<|/det|>
\[x = x_{0}\sin \omega t\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[444, 628, 580, 645]]<|/det|>
\[x = x_{0}\exp (-\lambda t)\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[444, 655, 536, 689]]<|/det|>
\[\lambda = \frac{0.693}{t_{\frac{1}{2}}}\]

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[453, 73, 542, 89]]<|/det|>
## Section A  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[297, 103, 699, 120]]<|/det|>
Answer all the questions in the spaces provided.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 149, 96, 168]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 149, 146, 168]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 149, 479, 167]]<|/det|>
Define gravitational potential at a point.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[850, 212, 875, 230]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 244, 146, 263]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 244, 868, 263]]<|/det|>
The gravitational potential \(\phi\) at distance \(r\) from point mass \(M\) is given by the expression  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 272, 524, 303]]<|/det|>
\[\phi = -\frac{GM}{r}\]  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 320, 460, 338]]<|/det|>
where \(G\) is the gravitational constant.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 351, 670, 369]]<|/det|>
Explain the significance of the negative sign in this expression.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[850, 444, 875, 462]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 475, 146, 492]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 475, 873, 524]]<|/det|>
A spherical planet may be assumed to be an isolated point mass with its mass concentrated at its centre. A small mass \(m\) is moving near to, and normal to, the surface of the planet. The mass moves away from the planet through a short distance \(h\).  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 536, 873, 570]]<|/det|>
State and explain why the change in gravitational potential energy \(\Delta E_{\mathrm{p}}\) of the mass is given by the expression  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[422, 583, 530, 600]]<|/det|>
\[\Delta E_{\mathrm{p}} = mgh\]  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 613, 470, 630]]<|/det|>
where \(g\) is the acceleration of free fall.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[850, 800, 875, 817]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 73, 148, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 73, 875, 107]]<|/det|>
The planet in **(c)** has mass \(M\) and diameter \(6.8 \times 10^{3} \text{km}\). The product \(G M\) for this planet is \(4.3 \times 10^{13} \text{N} \text{m}^{2} \text{kg}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 120, 875, 168]]<|/det|>
A rock, initially at rest a long distance from the planet, accelerates towards the planet. Assuming that the planet has negligible atmosphere, calculate the speed of the rock as it hits the surface of the planet.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[514, 333, 875, 351]]<|/det|>
<form>speed = ................................................. m s\(^{-1}\) [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 75, 96, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 75, 146, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 75, 737, 92]]<|/det|>
The kinetic theory of gases is based on some simplifying assumptions.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 90, 838, 122]]<|/det|>
The molecules of the gas are assumed to behave as hard elastic identical spheres. State the assumption about ideal gas molecules based on

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 136, 180, 154]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 136, 440, 153]]<|/det|>
the nature of their movement,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[845, 136, 875, 153]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 227, 181, 244]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 227, 303, 244]]<|/det|>
their volume.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[845, 320, 875, 338]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 73, 148, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 73, 875, 107]]<|/det|>
A cube of volume \(V\) contains \(N\) molecules of an ideal gas. Each molecule has a component \(c_{\mathrm{X}}\) of velocity normal to one side S of the cube, as shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[322, 114, 720, 300]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[443, 308, 509, 326]]<|/det|>
<pre>Fig. 2.1

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 338, 875, 356]]<|/det|>
The pressure \(p\) of the gas due to the component \(c_{\chi}\) of velocity is given by the expression

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[420, 365, 534, 386]]<|/det|>
\[pV = Nmc_{\chi}{}^{2}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 394, 450, 411]]<|/det|>
where \(m\) is the mass of a molecule.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 424, 552, 440]]<|/det|>
Explain how the expression leads to the relation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[406, 450, 546, 473]]<|/det|>
\[pV = \frac{1}{3} Nm < c^2 >\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 488, 618, 505]]<|/det|>
where \(< c^2>\) is the mean square speed of the molecules.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[848, 675, 876, 693]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 702, 146, 721]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 702, 875, 734]]<|/det|>
The molecules of an ideal gas have a root-mean-square (r.m.s.) speed of \(520 \text{ms}^{-1}\) at a temperature of \(27^{\circ}\text{C}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 745, 737, 762]]<|/det|>
Calculate the r.m.s. speed of the molecules at a temperature of \(100^{\circ}\text{C}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[460, 928, 875, 945]]<|/det|>
<form>r.m.s. speed = .................................................... $\text{ms}^{-1}$ [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 946, 551, 958]]<|/det|>
9702/43/M/J/12

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[826, 945, 918, 960]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 96, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 146, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 197, 608, 214]]<|/det|>
The heater in an electric kettle has a power of \(2.40 \text{kW}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 212, 875, 244]]<|/det|>
When the water in the kettle is boiling at a steady rate, the mass of water evaporated in 2.0 minutes is \(106 \text{g}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 243, 656, 260]]<|/det|>
The specific latent heat of vaporisation of water is \(2260 \text{Jg}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 274, 875, 306]]<|/det|>
Calculate the rate of loss of thermal energy to the surroundings of the kettle during the boiling process.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[475, 475, 875, 492]]<|/det|>

The sphere has a radius of \(25 \text{cm}\). Electrical breakdown (a spark) occurs in the air surrounding the sphere when the electric field strength at the surface of the sphere exceeds \(1.8 \times 10^4 \text{V} \text{cm}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 73, 875, 106]]<|/det|>
Two long straight parallel copper wires A and B are clamped vertically. The wires pass through holes in a horizontal sheet of card PQRS, as shown in Fig. 7.1.

<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[443, 457, 509, 475]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 488, 146, 507]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 488, 660, 505]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 504, 873, 535]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[880, 78, 944, 120]]<|/det|>
<form>Examiner's Use</FORM>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 104, 146, 122]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 104, 725, 120]]<|/det|>
This technique involves the use of two superimposed magnetic fields.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 120, 581, 136]]<|/det|>
Describe the functions of these two magnetic fields.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[840, 306, 875, 324]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 336, 148, 354]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 335, 875, 368]]<|/det|>
The frequency \(f\) of the electromagnetic waves emitted by protons on relaxation in an MR scanner is given by the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 380, 515, 397]]<|/det|>
\[f = 2cB\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 412, 875, 460]]<|/det|>
where \(B\) is the total magnetic flux density and \(c\) is a constant equal to \(1.34 \times 10^{8} \text{s}^{-1} \text{T}^{-1}\). The magnetic flux density changes by \(2.0 \times 10^{-4} \text{T}\) for each \(1.0 \text{cm}\) thickness of tissue in a section.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 460, 747, 477]]<|/det|>
The scanner is adjusted so that the thickness of each section is \(3.0 \text{mm}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 491, 655, 508]]<|/det|>
Calculate, for corresponding points in neighbouring sections,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 522, 180, 540]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 522, 510, 539]]<|/det|>
the difference in magnetic flux density,

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[365, 705, 875, 723]]<|/det|>
\[\text{difference in flux density} = \text{.................................................... T} \text{[1]}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 737, 181, 755]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 737, 465, 753]]<|/det|>
the change in emitted frequency.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[416, 922, 875, 938]]<|/det|>
<form>frequency change = .................................................... Hz [2]
